name: vscode-openshift-connector
description: Fast iterative application development on Red Hat OpenShift and Kubernetes
author: Red Hat

scripts.clean: shx rm -rf out/build out/src out/test out/tools out/test-resources out/*Viewer out/**.tsbuildinfo
scripts.test: npm run vscode:prepublish && node ./out/build/install-vscode.js && node ./out/build/run-tests.js unit
scripts.test-integration:coverage: npm run vscode:prepublish && npm run test:instrument && node ./out/build/run-tests.js integration
scripts.test:instrument: shx rm -rf out/src-orig && shx mv out/src out/src-orig && istanbul instrument --complete-copy --embed-source --output out/src out/src-orig
scripts.test:coverage: npm run build && npm run test:instrument && node ./out/build/install-vscode.js && node ./out/build/run-tests.js unit
scripts.build: npm run clean && npm run lint && npm run compile && npm run bundle-tools
scripts.cluster-ui-test: extest setup-and-run out/test/ui/cluster-ui-test.js -o test/ui/settings.json -m test/ui/.mocharc.js -e ./test-resources/extensions -c max -i
scripts.public-ui-test: extest setup-and-run out/test/ui/public-ui-test.js -o test/ui/settings.json -m test/ui/.mocharc.js -e ./test-resources/extensions -c max -i

commands.title: Login into Cluster using URL and token from clipboard
Open Console Dashboard for Current Cluster
Deploy it in your public cloud
Open Add OpenShift Local Setup Workflow
Create Deployment from Container Image URL
Start Dev on Podman (manually trigger rebuild)

viewsWelcome.contents:
Cluster is not accessible or you are not logged in.
[Login](command:openshift.explorer.login)
[Select Kubernetes Context](command:openshift.explorer.switchContext)
[Add OpenShift Cluster](command:openshift.explorer.addCluster)

You have no OpenShift Components in your workspace yet.
You can create an OpenShift component from a local codebase, a remote git repository, or a template project.
[Create Component](command:openshift.component.openCreateComponent)

explorer/context.when: explorerResourceIsFolder && explorerResourceIsRoot && resourceFilename not in ext.folderContainsDevfile

view/item/context/createService.when: view == openshiftProjectExplorer && isLoggedIn && viewItem =~ /openshift.project.*/i && isOpenshiftCluster && showCreateRoute

view/item/context.when: view == openshiftProjectExplorer && viewItem == openshift.k8sContext && canCreateNamespace && isOpenshiftCluster
view == openshiftComponentTypesView && viewItem == devfileRegistry && viewItem != DefaultdevfileRegistry
view == openshiftComponentTypesView && viewItem == devfileRegistry && viewItem != DefaultdevfileRegistry

walkthroughs.title: Getting Started with OpenShift Toolkit
walkthroughs.description: Start your application development on OpenShift or Kubernetes

steps.title: Login/Provision OpenShift cluster
steps.description:
Users can Login to an existing OpenShift cluster using the login button.
To provision a new OpenShift cluster, **Add OpenShift Cluster** button opens a guided workflow to provision a local, sandbox or hyrid cloud cluster.
[Login to the existing OpenShift cluster](command:openshift.explorer.login)
[Provision local OpenShift cluster](command:openshift.explorer.addCluster?["crc"])
[Provision Red Hat Developer Sandbox cluster](command:openshift.explorer.addCluster?["sandbox"])

steps.title: Create Component
steps.description:
By clicking on the '+' in the Components view in the OpenShift sidebar, you can configure a project so that it can be run on OpenShift/Kubernetes. You can import an existing local codebase, import an existing remote git repository, or create a new project from a template.
[Create Component](command:openshift.component.openCreateComponent)

media.altText: Screencast of creating a component from a git repository

steps.title: Create Component from workspace folder
steps.description: If you right click on a root folder in the explorer, you can use the `Create Component From Folder` option to create a component from that folder directly.

steps.title: Create Component from Devfile registries webview
steps.description:
Select a specific devfile registry to create a component from a template project more quickly.
[Browse Devfile Registries](command:openshift.componentTypesView.registry.openInView)

steps.title: Work with Helm Charts
steps.description:
Browse the catalog to discover and install Helm Charts.
[Browse Helm Chart](command:openshift.helm.openView)

steps.title: Deploy Container Image from URL
steps.description: In the Application Explorer sidebar panel, expand the tree item corresponding to the OpenShift/Kubernetes cluster, then right click on the project, and select "Create..." > "Create Deployment from Container Image URL". You will be asked to enter the URL to the container image and enter a name for the deployment. Once you've submitted this information, the Deployment will be created, and the logs for the first container created as a part of the Deployment will be opened in the OpenShift Terminal.

media.altText: Creating a Deployment of the Docker Hub MongoDB container image called my-mongo-db using the steps from the description

steps.title: Start a component in development mode
steps.description:
This is inner loop development and allows you to code, build, run and test the application in a continuous workflow. It continuously watches the directory for any new changes and automatically syncs them with the application running on the cluster.

 This also forwards a port on the development system to the port on the container cluster allowing you remote access to your deployed application

steps.title: Debug the component
steps.description: Start the component in debug mode. The devfile.yaml should be specified with the debug port as an endpoint for the debug to work.

steps.title: Deploy component on the cluster
steps.description: Deploy components in a similar manner they would be deployed by a CI/CD system, by first building the images of the containers to deploy, then by deploying the OpenShift/Kubernetes resources necessary to deploy the components.

walkthroughs.title: Getting Started with OpenShift Serverless Functions
walkthroughs.description: Develop & Deploy Serverless Functions using VSCode.

steps.title: Create Function
steps.description:
Creates a Function in the mentioned directory with the specified language/runtime selected and handles HTTP events. 
[Create Function](command:openshift.Serverless.createFunction)

steps.title: Create Function using git template
steps.description:
Creates a Function in the mentioned directory with the specified git based template selected. 
[Create Function](command:openshift.Serverless.createFunction)

steps.title: Build Function
steps.description: Build a function project (source code in the workspace) as a container image and push to a registry.

steps.title: Run the Function locally
steps.description:
Run your function to see how it works locally before to push it on your cluster.
Only a function which has the source code opened in the IDE can be run. Right click on the function you want to run (look for its node in the Functions tree), open the context menu (right-click on the node) and click on "Run". The output channel will show up with run command where you can see the logs.

steps.title: Deploy the Function
steps.description:
Deploys a function to the currently configured Knative-enabled cluster from your IDE.
Only a function which has the source code opened in the IDE can be pushed. Right-click on the function you want to deploy (look for its node in the Functions tree), open the context menu (right-click on the node) and click on "Deploy". The Output Channel will show up with the deploy command where you can see the logs.

steps.title: Invoke a Function
steps.description:
Invokes the function by sending a test request to the currently running function instance, either locally or remote.
Only a function which has the source code opened in the IDE can be invoked. Right-click on the function you want to invoke (look for its node in the Functions tree), open the context menu (right-click on the node) and click on "Invoke". Provide all necessary details and click on Invoke. 
Note: The function need to be run before invoke it.

openshiftToolkit.disable-context-info-st.description: Disable displaying the current Kubernetes context in VS Code's status bar.

openshiftToolkit.disable-namespace-info-.description: Disable displaying the active namespace in VS Code's status bar.

openshiftToolkit.showWelcomePage.description: Show welcome page when using OpenShift Toolkit extension.

openshiftToolkit.showChannelOnOutput.description: Show OpenShift Toolkit output channel when new text added to output stream.

openshiftToolkit.outputVerbosityLevel.description: Output verbosity level (value between 0 and 9) for OpenShift Create, and Dev commands in output channel and integrated terminal.

openshiftToolkit.outputFormat.description: Output format for Kubernetes specs. One of 'json' or 'yaml' (default).

openshiftToolkit.searchForToolsInPath.description: Force extension to search for `oc` and `odo` CLI tools in PATH locations before using bundled binaries.

openshiftToolkit.stopDevModeTimeout.description: Controls stopping development mode timeout (in milliseconds).

openshiftToolkit.execMaxBufferLength.description: MiB of memory to allocate for stdout buffer when executing a binary

openshiftToolkit.crcBinaryLocation.description: Provide the path where the OpenShift Local executable is present.

openshiftToolkit.crcCpuCores.description: Number of CPU cores to allocate to the OpenShift cluster as selected during the first run

openshiftToolkit.crcMemoryAllocated.description: MiB of memory to allocate to the OpenShift cluster as selected during the first run

openshiftToolkit.crcNameserver.description: IP address/name of DNS to use with OpenShift Local

configuration.title: Developer Sandbox for Red Hat OpenShift

openshiftToolkit.sandboxApiTimeout.description: Controls timeout (im milliseconds) for requests to OpenShift Sandbox Registration Service. Increase timeout value in case of unexpected errors in OpenShift Sandbox Provisioning workflow.
